comment: /* Turkish (Shaman & Islamic) */ added turkish translation of the Turkish word "being in love"

diff.*:
Line 206: Line 206:      
===Turkish (Shaman & Islamic)===
 
===Turkish (Shaman & Islamic)===
−
In [[Turkish language|Turkish]], the word "love" comes up with several meanings. A person can love a god, a person, parents, or family. But that person can "love" just one person from the opposite sex, which they call the word "aşk." ''[[Ishq|Aşk]]'' is a feeling for ''to love'', as it still is in Turkish today. The Turks used this word just for their loves in a romantic or sexual sense. If a Turk says that he is in love (aşk) with somebody, it is not a love that a person can feel for his or her parents; it is just for one person, and it indicates a huge infatuation. The word is also common for [[Turkic languages]], such as [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]] (eşq) and [[Kazakh language|Kazakh]] (ғашық).
+
In [[Turkish language|Turkish]], the word "love" comes up with several meanings. A person can love a god, a person, parents, or family. But that person can "love" just one person from the opposite sex, which they call the word "aşk." ''[[Ishq|Aşk]]'' is a feeling for ''to love,'' or being "in love" (Aşkim), as it still is in Turkish today. The Turks used this word just for their loves in a romantic or sexual sense. If a Turk says that he is in love (aşk) with somebody, it is not a love that a person can feel for his or her parents; it is just for one person, and it indicates a huge infatuation. The word is also common for [[Turkic languages]], such as [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]] (eşq) and [[Kazakh language|Kazakh]] (ғашық).
